div3.head: The United States and England.
div3.p:
It is clear from many unmistakable, indications, that the Northern people and Government are profoundly indignant at the conduct of England in this war. That hate is none the less intense, because prudence and policy require it for the time to be suppressed.
The remark attributed to McClellan that, as soon as he had succeeded in reconstructing the Union, his great desire was to see both sections unite in a war against England, expresses the sentiment of the great mass of the Northern nation.
It is in vain that England has marked out for herself a course of rigid neutrality.
Her very first step, in acknowledging the South a belligerent power, gave mortal offence to the Federal Government, which regards the South as a rebel, and expects the whole world to do the same.
The expressions of public sentiment in her press in favor of the South, and above all, the Mason and Slidell affair, have enkindled in the Northern mind a degree of rancor and haired second only to that which they bear towards the Southern Confederacy.
The North and West have always been more hostile to England than the South, which on various occasions, under the old Government, interposed to prevent a rupture between the two countries.
Recent events have not softened the ancient bitterness, and at this moment the subjugation of the South would scarcely afford the North a satisfaction as profound as the opportunity of a united and successful war with England.

It is altogether too late, in Northern opinion, for England to undo what she has done.
The flattering tone of a portion of the British press to the North is attributed, of course, to the desire to propitiate a combatant whose chances of success appear to be improving.
The Yankees have not forgotten how they were jeered at and despised when their prospects were rather blue, and their wrath is only deepened by the soft sander now applied to them by journals which, six months ago, were over flowing with scorn and denunciation.
Moreover, they have never doubted that the division of the old Union has been brought about by the arts and influence of Great Britain for the purpose of gratifying her revenge and getting rid, at the same time, of a formidable commercial and manufacturing rival.
They declare that, under the affected sympathy of England with their "American cousins." they perceive the most intense delight at the success of British schemes in bringing about that ruin which their arms were unable to accomplish, in causing the disruption of a country which is looked upon by the civilized world as a nation of lawless adventurers, and in relieving England from that hateful dependence upon America for cotton, which has compelled her to put up with so many insults and indignities from the United States.
The Yankees hold England responsible for every dollar that has been expended in this war, and, in their secret hearts, intend some day to confiscate Canada and all the British possessions on this continent, as well as the South.
And in that war they expect to have the co-operation of the Southern States.

This is an expectation quite in keeping with the character of this interesting people.
They appear to think that this war is all child's play, a mere fish cuff between two boys, which can be made up as soon as it is over, and both be as good friends as ever.
To the invaders, whose homes have never been molested, nor a hostile gun fired upon their soil, all this may be sport, and be forgotten with facility.
But we, the invaded — we, whose children have been murdered, whose homes have been burned, whose rights, property, and feelings have been outraged in every shape and form — can scarcely be expected to look upon all this as a nine-days' wonder.
The ashes of our dwellings, the ruin of our fortunes, the vacant chairs in every household, will be remembrances to us of this war which time and circumstance have no opiate to make us forget.
Even were it possible to conquer us, our hate of the murderous villains would only be the more profound, implacable, and eternal.
We can not what may be the responsibility of England for the present state of things in America.
It may be that through British policy the Union has been overthrown; but we can scarcely make England responsible for the spirit and temper in which the war has been conducted.
On the contrary, the ferocious and cruel purposes of the North have been repeatedly rebuked by the organs of British public sentiment, and, we have no doubt, have been retained by the indignant public opinion of that country.
The "Beauty and Booty" banners with which they inaugurated the war in New York, their determination to hang Confederate privateers, their stone blockade and other barbarities, awakened in England an outburst of denunciation which, however much they pretended to disregard it, was not without its effect.
But we care not what has been the course of England.
The South will never be diverted from the instruments of those unspeakable wrongs under which we suffer, by the excitement of a war between the United States and any European Government, except so far as to give that Government its best wishes, its deepest sympathies, its most earnest prayers, for the complete defeat and destruction of the United States.
Any aid and comfort that any Southern man could render to that end would be cheerfully given.
Should the South be conquered — of which there is not the most remote prospect — any foreign enemy of the United States would be welcome to our shores, would have every advantage that our territory could afford, and our co-operation in every way and shape confer.
Frenchman, Englishman, Austrian, Russian, or Turk — that nation which is the enemy of the United States is our friend and brother.
We would a thousand times rather be under the dominion of England or France than of the detestable Yankee tyrants who are robbing and murdering us for no other purpose than to force their wooden nutmegs down our throats, and make us their hewers of wood and drains of water to the end of time.

div3.p: --Gen, McClellan's official statement of the Federal loss in the battle below Richmond is as follows: Killed, eight hundred and ninety; wounded, three thousand six hundred and twenty- seven; missing, one thousand two hundred and twenty-two, making a grand total of killed wounded and missing of five thousand seven hundred and thirty-nine.

At a meeting of the Salem Flying Artillery, held on the 13th day of June, 1862, the death of John W. Howbert, a member of said company, having been announced, the following members of the company, viz: John M. Harlowe, jr., Samuel H. Nowlin, Samuel Parrish, and Lieut. C. B. Griffin, were appointed a committee to draft resolutions in reference thereto, who, at a subsequent meeting of the company, submitted the following preamble and resolutions; which were unanimously adopted:
Whereas, an all-wise God, in His inscrutable providence, has seen fit to remove from our midst our fellow-soldier and comrade in arms, John W. Howbert, of Roanoke county, Va: Therefore,

Resolved, list, That while we recognize in this dispensation of Divine Providence the great truth that "God moves in a mysterious way, we should submit, remembering "He is too wise to err, and too good to be unkind;" and while we deeply deplore his loss, we can but feel profoundly grateful to a gracious God for His signal protection over us as a company, this being the first of our comrades called from our midst by the hand of death during a 12 months services of the larger portion of the members of our company.

Resolved, 2d, That we, together with his relatives and friends, in this sudden bereavement, are impressively admonished that, "in such an hour as we think not the messenger of death may call for us;" that is the midst of life we are in death; therefore, we should wisely prepare for that change which must surely, sooner or later come to us all.
Resolved, 3d, That we extend our heartfelt condolence and earnest sympathies to the relatives and friends of the deceased.

Resolved, 4th, That a copy of these resolutions be forwarded to the parents of our deceased comrade, and also to the editors of the Richmond Dispatch, with a request to publish the name in their paper.
John M. Harlowe, Jr., sec'ry.
C. B. Griffin.
Samuel Parrish,
Samuel, H. Nowlin.

div3.head: War movements in Tennessee.
div3.p:
--A dispatch from Augusta, dated yesterday, says: The enemy, reported 10,000 strong, under Gen. Morgan, has fallen back from Powell's Valley towards Big Creek Gap, from the advance of our columns.
Gen. Nagle's force, 6,000 strong, is reported to be advancing by way of Pikeville towards Kingston and Knoxville.

It is supposed that Gen. Morgan is waiting for Nagle's arrival before risking a battle.
The enemy in Sequatchie is reported as having attempted to cross the Tennessee river this morning, three miles below Shell Mound, but were, driven back by Col. Davis, with the Florida forces.
Green Roberts, one of Morgan's men, made his escape from the Nashville penitentiary, and arrived at Chattanooga to-day.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, at Camp Winder Hospital, June 13th, from typhoid fever and hemorrhage, Lieut. N. W. Smith, Company A, 18th Mississippi Volunteers, in the 24th year of his age.

Lieut. Smith was one of three sons who gallantly volunteered to serve their country at the beginning of this arduous and trying struggle.
Deceased had seen much service, being present and a participator in Bull Run, Manassas, Harper's Ferry, Leesburg; and while subject to many hardships and extreme exposure at the Yorktown lines, nobly bore up against fell disease there engendered during the discharge of active military duty.
Lieut. Smith was much esteemed for many good qualities, and was a young officer of much promise.
He expired calmly and sweetly in his mother's arms, the good old lady having arrived at his bedside some few hours before his death.

list.item:
I. At the expiration of their term of service all paroled prisoners who are not enlisted for the war will have their names dropped from the muster rolls, and will be discharged the service of the Confederate States.
The commissions of the officers will expire with the terms of their men.

II.
No persons other than those authorized by the commanding General of an army, or the commanding officers of districts under martial law, shall be recognized as agents for taking possession of private property.
These agents, before making any impressments, shall present their written authority, and when they take property their receipts shall designate the officer who is to pay for it.

III.
Congress having conferred on the President the right, during the existing war. "to take such control of the lines of the telegraph in the Confederate States, and of such officers connected therewith as will enable him effectually to supervise the communications passing through the same." and to exercise other powers in reference to telegraph lines and the President having charged the Postmaster General with the discharge of these duties requisitions for building lines, the establishment and discontinuance of offices, the appointment of operators and agents, the disposition of material, &c., must be addressed to the Postmaster General, and officers are prohibited from exercising these powers.

IV.
To prevent misconception with reference to the discharge of men under 18 and over 35 years of age, under the Conscript act, the army is informed that only such persons as have not re-enlisted for three years or the war will be entitled to their discharge on the 16th of July next.
Those of the ages above mentioned who have so re-enlisted, whether they are in 12 months regiments or war regiments, are not entitled to a discharge until they have served out the term of enlistment.

V. Regimental medical officers when in charge of patients brought to general hospitals, or in the vicinity of the same, will turn them over to the surgeons in charge, and return without delay to their legitimate duties.
